results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This is a home movie from the Michaelis family of early Melbourne. ‘Australian Scenes’ is the title on screen and starts with a lovely view from the Yarra looking back to the city skyline. The river bank is packed as an exciting rowing regatta takes place. A great shot facing south from the top of Swanston Street and then the Shrine of Remembrance. We see a passing parade of Australian Army personnel in their slouch hats. A crowd on the steps of the Old Treasury Building. ‘Flemington, Cup Day, 1940’ is next with crowds of men in hats and wide shots of the running of the race and winners circle. A tennis match is played in front of a sold-out crowd in the ‘1946 Davis Cup Challenge’ at Kooyong’s tennis courts. A very scenic ‘Picnic at Warrandyte’ reflects a relaxing day out with the family in the country. There is footage of Australian native animals at what is possibly Healesville Sanctuary. ‘Bayside Scenes’ shows families enjoying the cooling waters of Port Phillip Bay. ‘Autumn at Macedon’ is a brief scene of trees in autumn colours. We then see the 1956 Olympic Games opening in Melbourne and the parade of athletes, releasing doves and the lighting of the flame. The film shows some events shot from the stands.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:35:00:00 rowing regatta on the Yarra
00:52:00:00 Melbourne street scene with vintage cars and tram #64. Facing south from the top end of Swanston Street.
00:59:00:00 St Kilda Road with Shrine of Remembrance in the distance; tram tracks and vintage cars
00:01:15:00 Shrine of Remembrance with people assembled on stairs
00:01:23:00 Melbourne Street scene, pedestrians and cars
00:01:28:00 possibly an Anzac Day march led by an army band and followed by soldiers
00:01:54:00 spectators crowd on the steps on the Old Treasury Building
00:02:06:00 Melbourne Cup Day, Flemington 1940. Punters crowd around the bookmakers – one being M. Labb
00:02:19:00 race horses being led around the mounting yard
00:02:47:00 footage of race (possibly the Melbourne Cup) shot from the grand stand
00:03:00:00 officials and jockey Andy Knox assemble for the cup presentation
00:03:07:00 1946 Davis Cup Challenge footage of Kooyong Centre Court and crowds in the grandstand
00:03:41:00 men’s singles match footage
00:03:51:00 men’s doubles match footage
00:04:29:00 close-up of the Davis Cup trophy with onlookers inspecting it
00:04:43:00 river in Warrandyte with swimmers on the bank
00:05:06:00 an old-style fireplace bush BBQ with chops and a billy boiling on the grill
00:05:10:00 close-up of a delicious looking BBQ’d lamb chop
00:05:13:00 family bush picnic in bucolic surrounds, eating picnic fare and sitting on blankets
00:05:23:00 rural scene with lake or dam and cabins with smoking chimneys and vintage cars parked around the cabins
00:08:46:00 Melbourne Olympic Games 1956 Opening Ceremony booklet or program
00:08:51:00 exterior of Melbourne Olympic stadium
00:09:09:00 interior of the Olympic stadium
00:09:40:00 atheletes enter the main stadium for the opening march and parade around the track
00:10:41:00 doves are released in to the stadium
00:10:48:00 Ron Clarke enters the stadium carrying the Olympic torch
00:10:58:00 shot of the Olympic cauldron alight with country flags in the background
00:11:26:00 track and field winners on podium

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains great footage of a trip to Japan, including urban scenes, Japanese cars, visits to temples and socialising with Japanese locals.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 aeroplanes on the tarmac
00:00:14:00 view from the plane as it takes off, including the Sydney Opera House and the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:01:32:00 coastline from the plane
00:01:45:00 view from the plane, Bali International Airport Ngurah Rai
00:02:20:00 scenes in Japan
00:03:00:00 feeding the deer, probably at Nara
00:03:30:00 Tōdai-ji, Nara (temple complex)
00:04:05:00 Bishamonten statue, Tōdai-ji, Nara
00:04:45:00 in the forest and visiting temples
00:05:41:00 a cute Japanese toddler in pink overalls
00:07:35:00 driving through city streets, views from the window of a bus
00:08:55:00 groups of Japanese schoolchildren having their photo taken at a temple
00:11:17:00 a fish pond with a waterfall (Ninomaru Garden and pond, Nijo Castle, Kyoto)
00:11:35:00 people viewing didactic map of Nijo Castle complex, Kyoto
00:14:00:00 cable car on a busy city street
00:15:08:00 neon sign ‘Matsushita Electric’
00:17:53:00 orderly city streets filled with traffic
00:20:10:00 View of Mt Fuji
00:20:55:00 close-ups of group of Japanese friends at dinner, all laughing and pulling faces at the camera
00:22:43:00 bright neon billboards at night
00:24:00:00 Coca-Cola billboard
00:25:02:00 view of city buildings from a plane landing
00:26:00:00 views across the harbour of a city (possibly Hong Kong)
00:28:34:00 double decker cable cars covered in advertising

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Dorothy Nixon and two companions are part of a travel trip as indicated by their name tags
00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film captures family holidays at Port Stephens, Point Roadknight and Ocean Grove, Victoria and Christmas in 1978. The family also goes fishing, plays tennis at the Geelong Lawn Tennis Club, attends a family wedding and enjoys some snow in Geelong.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Karen playing tennis
00:01:19:00 Karen sitting with a camera shy friend after the tennis
00:01:33:00 Dorothy and Stuart
00:02:00:00 scenes inside a holiday house, perhaps at Port Stephens
00:02:34:00 teenagers Karen and Stuart playing cards on a couch in the holiday flat
00:03:07:00 Dorothy, Stuart and Karen on the balcony of a holiday flat
00:04:09:00 scenes of the beach on holiday, a kookaburra in a tree and some swimming
00:05:27:00 an inflatable ‘Lilo’ mat on the water
00:06:36:00 posing for the camera with friends or relatives
00:07:58:00 scenes of the sea
00:10:05:00 late 1970s wedding in peachy coloured tones
00:13:30:00 more scenes at the beach
00:14:57:00 Stuart in school uniform
00:15:16:00 family members fishing
00:19:10:00 an extended family gathering
00:23:19:00 teenager Stuart gets a new adult size bicycle for Christmas
00:24:12:00 Dorothy holds up her new ‘Barry Crocker’ vinyl record album

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains footage of a visit to the Gresswell Sanatorium in Mont Park, Victoria, which at the time housed and treated male patients with tuberculosis. Mont Park was an area north-east of Melbourne comprising several health institutions, including the Gresswell Sanatorium which was named after Dan Gresswell, a public health administrator. The film provides an insightful look at life in the sanatorium, including recreational activities and health care.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 great example of a handpainted sign reading ‘Repatriation Sanatorium, Drive Slow, Gresswell Sanatorium’
00:00:13:00 a 1940s style bus with logo ‘Heidelberg Motor Omnibus Service Pty. Ltd.’
00:00:40:00 a woman in 1940s style dress disembarks the bus
00:01:22:00 three men walking down the road
00:01:58:00 a man using a grinding wheel in a work shed
00:03:11:00 meal time at the sanatorium
00:04:07:00 a cheeky group of people in conversation, with several poking their tongue out to the camera
00:06:18:00 playing cricket with branches amongst the trees
00:07:22:00 a patient being treated with an injection and valve, presumably to relieve air from the lung, a common treatment for tuberculosis at the time
00:08:56:00 nurse in uniform of the era with a long veil

This film is predominantly comprised of a trip through the Snowy Mountains, including some lovely footage of the landscape.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short film shows scenes of a holiday in Phillip Island, a popular holiday destination south-east of Melbourne, Victoria.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 views over the water
00:02:15:00 penguins and seals on the rocks
00:04:15:00 exploring the rock pools
00:05:00:00 plume of water crashing against the rocks
00:06:06:00 a short snippet of an Aboriginal woman

results.title: Heads
results.creator_credit: George Dixon, David Corke and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: An experimental film by a group of young Victorian filmmakers. Nonchalantly, the cleaner dusts the works of art created by ancient Greek potters, Renaissance painters and modern sculptors. Each piece marks the stage in our progress as percipient thinking beings: civilisations mature and die - but we survive, at least until today. As the cleaner blows dust from the ear of Epstein’s Einstein, he is ignorant of the terrible forces such a mind has unleashed; for good or ill these forces can, almost, be directed by a toss of a coin.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains three distinct scenes. The first is footage of an arts and crafts show, including jewellery, pottery and sculpture on display; the second is a man weaving a basket; and the third shows children and adolescents in a gymnastics class, practising somersaults, cartwheels and back flips.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 displays of jewellery and pottery
00:00:55:00 a girl in white cat eye glasses
00:01:51:00 a man basket weaving
00:02:28:00 a group of children and adolescents practising somersaults in a gymnastics class
00:04:05:00 cartwheels and back flips
